title: Verified Purchase
content: This book is about 2 sisters who lived in France during WWII during the German occupation.  The story of one of the sisters loosely follows the true story of the young Belgian girl, Monique Hanotte, who risked her life to help escort 135 Allied airman out of German occupied France and Belgium.  It was difficult to put down the book; I kept wondering what would be the fate of the 2 sisters and their families.  I was unaware that the French were treated so badly by the Germans - the Germans imposed near starvation upon the French.  The actions of the Germans are a reminder of how easy it is for ordinary decent people to slip into depravity.  I didn't rate it 5 stars because, even though it is a compelling story, I did not think the writing had the artistic depth of say a John Steinbeck.  It is still well worth the read.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on July 14, 2024

title: Fabulous read
content: I thought about putting this book down a couple times, but in the end glad I did not. This book gives you the POC of two sisters living in France during WWII and how their outlooks of the war and being taken over by the Germans effect their lives. No spoilers, but if you get it and think about putting it down DO NOT! The end of the book is hear wrenching and really has a great closer.

title: Verified Purchase
content: Found my eyes filling with tears at several points throughout this book. A stark reminder of how Socialism (which always eventually leads to Communism) is guaranteed to cause suffering, starvation, and death. There are a lot of parallels between the Nazis and today’s modern leftist Democrat party. What I did find a bit odd was the author’s choice with Isabelle. She was talking about a “Free France” and prosperity yet she joined up with Communists…There is no freedom or prosperity with Communism (quite the opposite). Socialism and Communism combined has killed well over 100 million people. Again, I found that to be a rather odd character choice. Otherwise I enjoyed this.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on August 14, 2024

title: Jjb
content: “If I had told him the truth long ago, or had danced and drunk and sung more, maybe he would have seen me instead of a dependable, ordinary mother. He loves a version of me that is incomplete. I always thought it was what I wanted: to be loved and admired. Now I think perhaps I’d like to be known.”

title: Verified Purchase
content: The Nightingale by Kristin Hannah follows two sisters, Vianne and Isabelle, in France during World War 2. Vianne, with her quiet strength, raises her daughter under the watchful eye of Nazi officers billeted at her home while her husband is away fighting. Isabelle, with her courage and bullheaded determination, works with a resistance group fighting the war in her own way.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on August 16, 2024

title: Have tissues ready!
content: This book ripped my heart out, y’all. I was ugly crying by the end of it. I should have expected it, as Kristin Hannah makes me cry every single time. I honestly didn’t expect it, though, because I have been burned out by books based in World War 2 era. It’s been years since I’ve picked on up…on purpose. Which explains why this book has been on my TBR since 2019 and only got read because it was a book club pick. I’m glad it was, as it was a 5 star read for me. Please be mindful of my trigger warnings, though, and take care of yourself, my friends.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on May 19, 2024

title: Verified Purchase

title: So beautiful and sad
content: I love reading WWII books, but this one was one I'll not forget.  I felt such an overwhelming heaviness of sadness, it spilled out into my day.  I don't know how so many survived.  At times, I had to put the book down and take a break.  There is no break in the turmoil, torture, and starvation for the jews and for the people of France.  Broke my heart.  It was a lot, all at once and some of it made me think....how could anyone be that cruel?
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on August 17, 2024

title: Verified Purchase
content: I know the author did a ton of research, it shows.  I kept hoping for one ounce of happiness or hope and there was none.  At first it made me put the book down, but then I thought . . . these people had no break either.  Would I read this book again?  No.  It was just too much for me but a story that many should read. If nothing else, so history does not repeat itself.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on May 3, 2024

title: another tale of strength about women's resilience during historical turmoil
content: As I sit down to write this, there's this odd feeling of emptiness and dryness pervading my thoughts. I once stumbled upon this idea that a good review should capture how a book makes you feel, and let me tell you, this one has stirred up so many emotions in me that I hardly know where to start. If I had to sum it up in just one word, I'd probably go with "beautiful" – simple yet profound.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on April 1, 2024

title: Verified Purchase
content: My usual go-to genre is thrillers and mysteries, but there's something about historical novels that always gets me. Especially those set against the backdrop of Asian cultures or the turmoil of World Wars I and II. The way authors, especially women like Kate Quinn, Kristin Hannah, and Min Jin Lee, delicately yet powerfully depict the horrors of war and the human spirit within it – it's absolutely mesmerizing.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on October 9, 2024

title: Loved the story
content: War has always felt like a distant concept to me. I come from a country untouched by its scars, and none of my relatives have ever lived through it either. And honestly, I'm grateful for that. But maybe it's this distance that makes me so drawn to reading about it, even through fiction. These stories give me a glimpse into lives lived amidst unimaginable pain and suffering. And while I know nothing can truly capture the horrors of war, I can't help but relate to the everyday struggles faced by those who lived through it. It's both humbling and inspiring to see the strength and resilience of the women who navigated these turbulent times, not just for themselves but for those they loved.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on September 27, 2024

title: Verified Purchase
content: In the words of Kristin Hannah herself, ""Men tell stories," I say. It is the truest, simplest answer to his question. “Women get on with it. For us, it was a shadow war. There were no parades for us when it was over, no medals or mentions in history books. We did what we had to during the war, and when it was over, we picked up the pieces and started our lives over.""
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on September 26, 2024

title: missing pages!!
